questions.text: A healthcare provider is assessing a postpartum mother with a viral infection for breastfeeding suitability. Given the mother's diagnosis, the provider must decide if breastfeeding should be contraindicated. Which viral infection in the mother commonly requires temporary cessation of breastfeeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Herpes Simplex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hepatitis B is not a contraindication for breastfeeding as long as the infant receives the appropriate vaccinations.
  • • Option
  • • A: Hepatitis B
  • • not a contraindication for breastfeeding
  • • Option B: Hepatitis C is generally not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding . Transmission through breast milk is not common, and breastfeeding may continue unless there is nipple bleeding.
  • • Option
  • • B: Hepatitis C
  • • not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding
  • • Option D: Varicella Zoster, responsible for chickenpox , is not a contraindication for breastfeeding if the mother has immunity before pregnancy or if the baby has received varicella zoster immune globulin.
  • • Option
  • • D: Varicella Zoster,
  • • chickenpox

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While most maternal viral infections do not prohibit breastfeeding , certain conditions like active herpes simplex lesions on the breasts can necessitate temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding on the affected side to prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.
  • ➤ maternal viral infections
  • ➤ not prohibit breastfeeding
  • ➤ active herpes simplex lesions
  • ➤ breasts
  • ➤ temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding
  • ➤ affected side
  • ➤ prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A 35-week-gestation infant, born to a mother with poorly controlled pregestational diabetes (insulin-dependent with vascular disease, HbA1C 9%), is delivered via cesarean section due to fetal macrosomia and distress. Neonate is at risk for several complications due to the maternal diabetes and premature birth. In addition to birth asphyxia, cardiac septal hypertrophy, and polycythemia, which of the following conditions is this infant at an increased risk for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyaline membrane disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Congenital dislocated hip is not specifically associated with maternal diabetes or prematurity but is related to factors like breech presentation and family history.
  • • Option A:
  • • Congenital dislocated hip
  • • not
  • • associated with maternal diabetes
  • • Option B: Dacryostenosis , or the obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct , is a common condition in newborns but is not directly linked to maternal diabetes or prematurity.
  • • Option B:
  • • Dacryostenosis
  • • obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct
  • • common condition in newborns
  • • Option D: Hyperglycemia is less common in infants of diabetic mothers immediately postpartum . These infants are typically at risk for hypoglycemia due to their own increased insulin production in response to maternal hyperglycemia before birth.
  • • Option D:
  • • Hyperglycemia is less common in infants
  • • diabetic mothers
  • • postpartum
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Hyaline membrane disease , also known as neonatal respiratory distress syndrome , is more common in preterm infants due to insufficient surfactant production . Infants of diabetic mothers , especially those with poor glycemic control , are at an increased risk for this condition, as maternal hyperglycemia can delay fetal lung maturity . The high levels of insulin in these infants , a response to maternal hyperglycemia , can further inhibit surfactant production , exacerbating the risk of respiratory distress syndrome.
  • • Hyaline membrane disease
  • • neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
  • • common in preterm infants
  • • insufficient surfactant production
  • • Infants of diabetic mothers
  • • poor glycemic control
  • • increased risk
  • • maternal hyperglycemia
  • • delay fetal lung maturity
  • • high levels of insulin
  • • infants
  • • maternal hyperglycemia
  • • inhibit surfactant production
  • • Ref - Nelson 21 st Edition page 3997
  • • Ref
  • • - Nelson 21 st Edition page 3997

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Polio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: B
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: C
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: D
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in FEV1> 15% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.correct_answer: C. Day- night variation of FEV1 > 15%
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 15%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in FEV1 > 15% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023) lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, gentle suction is applied to the nose and mouth if the baby is vigorous, and PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.
  • ➤ The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:
  • ➤ For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413
  • ➤ Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:
  • ➤ The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer
  • ➤ Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: A concerned father brings his 8-year-old son, Dev, to the pediatric clinic after noticing his frequent complaints of bone pain and a recent incident where a minor fall resulted in a fracture. During the examination, the pediatrician observes multiple healing fractures of varying ages on the X-rays, along with noticeable bruises on the skin. Initially, there is a suspicion of non-accidental injury, but further assessment reveals Dev has a short stature, distinctive blue sclera, and visible bone deformities in his limbs and spine. These findings suggest a genetic condition affecting bone strength rather than external trauma. What is the pattern of inheritance for Dev's diagnosed condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Autosomal Dominant

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The diagnosis based on the David’s history is Osteogenesis imperfecta and it is Autosomal Dominant in nature.
  • • Autosomal Dominant
  • • The clinical features include
  • • clinical features
  • • Multiple fractures: recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma. Can cause deformities or shortening of limbs. Blue sclera : Its due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities. Dental problems : Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly. ( Dentinogenesis imperfecta - The bluish, opalescent sheen on several teeth results from genetically defective dentin ). Hearing loss: Hearing loss occurs in approximately 20% of young children and as many as 50% of adults by the age of 50 Skeletal deformities : scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest). Short stature: due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth. Easy bruising : Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition.
  • • Multiple fractures: recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma. Can cause deformities or shortening of limbs.
  • • Multiple fractures:
  • • Blue sclera : Its due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities.
  • • Blue sclera
  • • Dental problems : Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly. ( Dentinogenesis imperfecta - The bluish, opalescent sheen on several teeth results from genetically defective dentin ).
  • • Dental problems
  • • Hearing loss: Hearing loss occurs in approximately 20% of young children and as many as 50% of adults by the age of 50
  • • Hearing loss:
  • • Skeletal deformities : scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest).
  • • Skeletal deformities
  • • Short stature: due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth.
  • • Short stature:
  • • Easy bruising : Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition.
  • • Easy bruising

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of frequent fractures from minimal trauma , blue sclera , short stature , and bone deformities , strongly suggests Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). OI is a genetic disorder primarily affecting collagen , leading to brittle bones and a susceptibility to fractures. The majority of OI cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner , meaning a single copy of the defective gene from either parent can cause the disorder.
  • ➤ frequent fractures from minimal trauma
  • ➤ blue sclera
  • ➤ short stature
  • ➤ bone deformities
  • ➤ Osteogenesis Imperfecta
  • ➤ genetic disorder primarily affecting collagen
  • ➤ brittle bones
  • ➤ susceptibility to fractures.
  • ➤ majority of OI cases
  • ➤ inherited in an autosomal dominant manner
  • ➤ Note - Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) (brittle bone disease) is the most common genetic cause of osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Note
  • ➤ Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • ➤ most common genetic cause of osteoporosis.
  • ➤ Ref: nelson 21 st Edition – Page No-14415-14427
  • ➤ Ref: nelson 21 st Edition – Page No-14415-14427

questions.text: On the initial day of treatment for a child diagnosed with Severe Acute Malnutrition, the attending physician calculates the dose of folic acid to administer. What is the standard initial dosage of folic acid for a child on the first day of SAM management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 mg

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The recommended initial dose of folic acid in the management of SAM is 5 mg on the first day and then 1 mg every day till day 14 of treatment .
  • • initial dose of folic acid in the management of SAM
  • • 5 mg on the first day
  • • 1 mg every day till day 14 of treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Management of SAM - Micronutrients supplementation
  • ➤ Management of SAM - Micronutrients supplementation
  • ➤ Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals. On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU) Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1) Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase.
  • ➤ Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals.
  • ➤ Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals.
  • ➤ On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU)
  • ➤ On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU)
  • ➤ Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1)
  • ➤ Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1)
  • ➤ Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day
  • ➤ Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day
  • ➤ Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day
  • ➤ Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day
  • ➤ Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase.
  • ➤ Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase.
  • ➤ Ref: Op Ghai 9 th Edition, Page No- 93.
  • ➤ Ref: Op Ghai 9 th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of some dehydration in a 5-year-old child? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lethargy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, whereas delayed skin pinch and sunken eyeballs can be signs of both some and severe dehydration in a 5-year-old child.

questions.text: During a routine neonatal examination, a nurse assesses a newborn's overall well-being using the apgar score, a quick and standardized evaluation performed at one and five minutes after birth. Considering the components of the apgar score, which of the following is not a factor included in this assessment tool?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Respiratory rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score evaluates five parameters: heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and skin color. Respiratory rate is not a component ; instead, respiratory effort is assessed.
  • ➤ Apgar score
  • ➤ heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and skin color. Respiratory rate is not a component

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in by their mother, who is distressed due to criticism from her mother-in-law regarding the child's health. The child has developmental delays, intellectual disability, and distinctive physical features including sandal gap toes. Recently, the child has been diagnosed with a congenital heart disease. Given the child's clinical features, as shown in the images, what is the most common congenital heart disease associated with this presentation ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endocardial Cushion defects

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical features of the child is pointing towards the diagnosis of Downs Syndrome. The most common congenital heart disease in case of Downs syndrome is Endocardial Cushion defects (AVSD)
  • • Downs Syndrome.
  • • Downs syndrome is Endocardial Cushion defects (AVSD)
  • • The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are.
  • • The clinical features
  • • Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye.
  • • Short neck Abnormally shaped ears White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots) Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand. Brachycephaly Protrudin g tongue Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.
  • • Short neck
  • • Abnormally shaped ears
  • • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand. Brachycephaly Protrudin g tongue Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.
  • • Brachycephaly Protrudin g tongue Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.
  • • Brachycephaly
  • • Protrudin g tongue
  • • Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.
  • • Option A, C and D aren’t the most common congenital heart disease in Downs Syndrome.
  • • Option A, C and D aren’t the most common
  • • congenital heart disease in Downs Syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Downs syndrome - Approximately 40% children have congenital heart disease . Endocardial cushion defects account for about 40-60% cases . Presence of heart disease is the most significant factor in determining survival. All children should have a cardiac evaluation before 9 months of age, including echocardiography.
  • ➤ Downs syndrome
  • ➤ 40% children have congenital heart disease
  • ➤ Endocardial cushion defects
  • ➤ 40-60% cases
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 20 th Edition, Page No 610-615.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 20 th Edition, Page No 610-615.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.correct_answer: B. Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Biliverdin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a premature infant is born with a birth weight of 850 grams. To categorize the degree of prematurity and guide appropriate medical interventions, the healthcare team refers to the extremely low birth weight (elbw) cutoff. What is the generally accepted elbw cutoff?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 500 grams; facilitating prompt respiratory support

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 750 grams; guiding nutritional interventions

options.label: C
options.text: Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 1,500 grams; indicating the need for developmental follow-up

questions.correct_answer: C. Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extremely Low Birth Weight (ELBW) is defined as a birth weight of less than 1,000 grams. These infants require specialized care due to their high risk of complications .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brain death is characterized by the complete absence of brain-originating motor responses, including decorticate and decerebrate posturing, despite possible preservation of autonomic functions like normal BP and spinal reflexes.

questions.text: A mother brings her 17-month-old child to the doctor for routine eye checkup. On examination the Doctor notices a thinned-out cornea. On asking history, the child has a history of iron deficiency anemia. The weight of the child is 10kg, what should be the dose of vitamin A to be given in this child of based on the age?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 2,00,000 IU

questions.text: A concerned mother visits your clinic with her 3-year-old child, worried about the child's inadequate growth. The child's medical history reveals a low birth weight, along with ongoing feeding difficulties and a poor appetite. Upon physical examination, you note several distinctive features: a prominent forehead, a small jaw, a narrow chin, and clinodactyly. These clinical findings, combined with the child's growth issues, lead you to consider a specific diagnosis. Based on the information provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Russell - Silver syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Russell-Silver Syndrome
  • • Russell-Silver Syndrome
  • • Most cases occur sporadically , chromosome 11p15 , maternal disomy of chromosome 7 .
  • • sporadically
  • • chromosome 11p15
  • • maternal disomy of chromosome 7
  • • Possible risks include:
  • • Possible risks include:
  • • Metabolic syndrome. Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males. Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density. Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).
  • • Metabolic syndrome.
  • • Metabolic syndrome.
  • • Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis
  • • Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis
  • • Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males.
  • • Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males.
  • • Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density.
  • • Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density.
  • • Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).
  • • Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uniparental disomy (UPD) is when a child gets both copies of a chromosome from one parent . This can lead to conditions like Prader-Willi syndrome (if both chromosome 15s come from the mother) and Angelman syndrome.
  • ➤ Uniparental disomy
  • ➤ child gets both copies of a chromosome from one parent
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome
  • ➤ Angelman syndrome.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition page 1696, 2987
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition page 1696, 2987

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: Identify the following instruments which are used for the measurement of the nutritional status of the child? 1. Harpenden caliper 2. Salters Scale 3. Shakir’s Tape 4. Infantometer
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Tape Measure : Used for measuring mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC), which is an important anthropometric measurement of nutritional status , particularly in identifying malnutrition in children .
  • • Option A. Tape Measure
  • • measuring mid-upper arm circumference
  • • important anthropometric measurement
  • • nutritional status
  • • malnutrition in children
  • • Option B. Infantometer : This device is used to measure the length or height of infants and small children . It is essential for assessing linear growth and determining stunting .
  • • Option B. Infantometer
  • • measure the length or height of infants
  • • small children
  • • assessing linear growth
  • • determining stunting
  • • Option C. Spring Scale : Often used for weighing infants and young children . The child is usually placed in a sling which is then attached to the scale.
  • • Option C. Spring Scale
  • • weighing infants and young children
  • • Option D. Skinfold Caliper : Utilized to measure skinfold thickness at various body sites to estimate body fat percentage , a key component in evaluating nutritional status.
  • • Option D. Skinfold Caliper
  • • measure skinfold thickness
  • • body sites to estimate body fat percentage
  • • Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition page number 1842
  • • Ref:
  • • Nelson 21 st Edition page number 1842

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: During a routine OPD session on Holi, a police officer brings in an unidentified child for age verification. To determine the child's age, you order a wrist X-ray. Upon reviewing the X-ray, you identify the age of the child to be approximately 2 months. Which of the following carpal bones did you primarily rely on to estimate the age of the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Capitate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Scaphoid will ossify by 4-6 years of age .
  • • Option A.
  • • Scaphoid
  • • ossify by 4-6 years of age
  • • Option C. Lunate will ossify by 2-4 years of age
  • • Option C.
  • • ossify by 2-4 years of age
  • • Option D. Trapezoid will ossify by 4-6 years of age.
  • • Option D.
  • • Trapezoid
  • • ossify by 4-6 years of age.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Although there is great individual variability, approximate ossification times are as follows:
  • ➤ Although there is great individual variability, approximate ossification times are as follows:
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition page 1127
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition page 1127

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? ? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a concerned mother presents her infant, worried about the child's weight gain. She compares her baby to her sister-in-law's seemingly healthier child. Upon examination, the infant appears active and alert. The mother reports that the birth weight was 2600 grams, and currently, the scale reads 5300 grams, indicating that the infant's weight has doubled. As an intern, you recall the standard growth milestones and reassure the mother. Based on standard pediatric growth patterns, at what age is an infant's weight expected to double from birth?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) 5 months

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The weight of the baby triples by 1 year of age and doubles by 5 months .
  • • Option A.
  • • weight of the baby triples by 1 year of age
  • • doubles by 5 months
  • • Option B. The weight of the baby becomes 4 times the birth weight by 2 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months .
  • • Option B.
  • • weight of the baby becomes 4 times the birth weight
  • • 2 years of age
  • • doubles by 5-6 months
  • • Option C. The weight of the baby becomes 5 times the birth weight by 3 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months .
  • • Option C.
  • • weight of the baby becomes 5 times
  • • birth weight by 3 years
  • • age and doubles by 5-6 months
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • Ref: OP Ghai 9 th Edition, Page No- 43-51.
  • • Ref:
  • • OP Ghai 9 th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about congenital CMV infection? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic

options.label: B
options.text: Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia

options.label: C
options.text: Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life

options.label: D
options.text: If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

questions.correct_answer: D. If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) If mother is IgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternal IgG positivity for CMV suggests a lower risk of congenital CMV transmission, making it less likely for the fetus to develop the infection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by their mother, who is concerned about the child's noticeably shorter stature compared to peers. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the child's short stature appears disproportionate, with a more significant discrepancy between the upper and lower body segments. Considering a potential diagnosis of a condition affecting growth, the pediatrician decides to assess the child's body proportions more closely by measuring the upper segment and lower segment ratios. Understanding the normal progression of body proportions from childhood to adulthood is crucial in this assessment. At what age do the upper and lower segments of the body typically reach adult proportions ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 10 years

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A - By the age of 2 years the ratio is 1.4:1
  • • Option A
  • • 2 years the ratio is 1.4:1
  • • Option C - By the age of 7 years the ratio is 1:1 whereas the adult ratio is 0.9:1
  • • Option C
  • • 7 years the ratio is 1:1
  • • adult ratio is 0.9:1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The upper-to-lower body segment ratio (U/L ratio) provides an assessment of truncal growth relative to limb growth . The lower-body segment is defined as the length from the top of the symphysis pubis to the floor , and the upper-body segment is the total height minus the lower-body segment.
  • ➤ upper-to-lower body segment ratio
  • ➤ assessment of truncal growth
  • ➤ limb growth
  • ➤ lower-body segment
  • ➤ length from the top of the symphysis pubis to the floor
  • ➤ upper-body segment
  • ➤ total height minus the lower-body segment.
  • ➤ The U/L ratio equals approximately 1.7 at birth, 1.3 at 3 year, and 1.0 after 7 year. Higher U/L ratios are characteristic of short-limb dwarfism, as occurs with Turner syndrome or bone disorders, whereas lower ratios suggest hypogonadism or Marfan syndrome.
  • ➤ Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51; Nelson 21 st Ed Pg 1183
  • ➤ Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51; Nelson 21 st Ed Pg 1183

questions.text: A medical student is rotating in the neonatal intensive care unit and is being quizzed on the identification and purpose of various neonatal care devices. The attending physician shows the student four images labeled A, B, C, and D, each depicting a different device. The student is asked to match the following devices with their corresponding names: Radiant Warmer Phototherapy unit Bilirubinometer Incubator
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A2 B1 C4 D3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A2 - Phototherapy Unit: Image A shows a neonate under a blue light , characteristic of a phototherapy unit used for treating hyperbilirubinemia in newborns by converting bilirubin into more soluble forms through structural isomerization.
  • • A2 - Phototherapy Unit:
  • • neonate under a blue light
  • • phototherapy unit
  • • treating hyperbilirubinemia
  • • newborns
  • • B1 - Radiant Warmer: Image B depicts a device used to maintain the body temperature of neonates by providing radiant heat . This is important for premature infants or those who cannot regulate their temperature.
  • • B1 - Radiant Warmer:
  • • device used to maintain the body temperature
  • • neonates
  • • providing radiant heat
  • • C4 - Incubator: Image C illustrates an enclosed apparatus designed to provide a controlled and protective environment for premature or ill newborns , which is indicative of an incubator.
  • • C4 - Incubator:
  • • enclosed apparatus designed to provide a controlled
  • • protective environment
  • • premature or ill newborns
  • • D3 - Bilirubinometer: Image D shows a handheld device being used on a neonate's forehead , which is typically a non-invasive bilirubinometer used to measure bilirubin levels in newborns .
  • • D3 - Bilirubinometer:
  • • handheld device being used on a neonate's forehead
  • • non-invasive bilirubinometer
  • • bilirubin levels in newborns
  • • Ref - Nelson 21 st Edition page 2190
  • • Ref
  • • Nelson 21 st Edition page 2190

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A 25-year-old mother named Mala delivered her first child at a primary health care center. The delivery was noted to be complicated, with the neonate having a delayed cry and subsequent development of neurological signs. The medical officer observed signs consistent with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) and promptly referred the newborn to a higher-level facility for further evaluation and management. Upon examination at the referral center, the neonate exhibited hypotonia, exaggerated ankle reflexes, recurrent focal seizures, and miotic pupils. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely stage of HIE according to the Sarnat and Sarnat staging system?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Stage 1 (Mild HIE): This stage is characterized by hyperalertness, jitteriness , increased muscle tone , irritable and exaggerated reflexes , without significant alterations in level of consciousness or seizures.
  • • Option A: Stage 1 (Mild HIE):
  • • hyperalertness, jitteriness
  • • increased muscle tone
  • • irritable
  • • exaggerated reflexes
  • • Option C: Stage 3 (Severe HIE): Neonates in this stage present with stupor or coma , flaccid muscle tone , absent reflexes , and often have severe autonomic dysfunction.
  • • Option C: Stage 3 (Severe HIE): Neonates
  • • stage present with stupor or coma
  • • flaccid muscle tone
  • • absent reflexes
  • • Option D: Stage 4 is not classed under Sarnat and Sarnat staging .
  • • Option D: Stage 4
  • • not classed under Sarnat
  • • Sarnat staging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref - Nelson 21 st Edition page 12509
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition page 12509

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath and fainting episode. On further evaluation features of short stature and webbed neck were noted. He was subjected to cardiological examination where he is diagnosed with pulmonary stenosis. A genetic testing was done in which chromosome 12 is found to be abnormal. On compiling all the history and clinical features he is diagnosed as a case of pseudo turner syndrome known as Noonan Syndrome. What is the gene responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. CLCN 7 gene mutation will results in osteopetrosis , a condition characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone growth.
  • • Option A.
  • • CLCN 7 gene mutation
  • • osteopetrosis
  • • Option C. CFTR gene mutation will result in Cystic Fibrosis , affecting the lungs, pancreas, and other organs.
  • • Option C.
  • • CFTR gene mutation
  • • Cystic Fibrosis
  • • Option D. ATM gene mutation will results in Ataxia Telangiectasia , rare inherited childhood neurological disorder that affects the part of the brain that controls motor movement (intended movement of muscles) and speech. The triad of symptoms includes progressive ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasias and sinopulmonary disease.
  • • Option D.
  • • ATM gene mutation
  • • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Turner Syndrome vs Noonan Syndrome
  • • Turner Syndrome vs Noonan Syndrome
  • • Ref: Nelson 21 st edition, Chapter 601– Page No 11714-11716
  • • Ref:
  • • Nelson 21 st edition, Chapter 601– Page No 11714-11716

questions.text: A Medical Officer in a Regional healthcare center is addressing concerns of a mother who is worried about her milk supply being inadequate for her infant's needs. The MO assures her that breast milk composition typically provides all necessary nutrients in the right amounts. To demonstrate this point, she quizzes the interns present, about the sodium content of breast milk. What is the sodium content in breast milk measured in mEq/L?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7 mEq/L

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Breast milk has a relatively low sodium content compared to other fluids , which is appropriate for the kidney's filtering capacity of an infant . On average, breast milk contains 7 mEq/L of sodium , which meets the infant's nutritional requirements without overloading their renal system.
  • • Breast milk
  • • relatively low sodium content
  • • other fluids
  • • appropriate for the kidney's filtering capacity
  • • infant
  • • breast milk contains 7 mEq/L of sodium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022) Bronchoscopy Computed tomography scan ICD insertion Chest x-ray
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: During rounds with your consultant, several cases of genetic diso rders in the pediatric ward were discussed. Your consultant asks about the most common chromosomal disorder, its complication, and its associated disorders. Match the following columns correctly to demonstrate your understanding and facilitate further discussion:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Some important points
  • • Some important points
  • • Nondisjunction - Common aneuploidies seen in live born babies include Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edward syndrome (trisomy 18), Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Turner syndrome (monosorny X). Chromosome deletion - William syndrome (7qll.23); retinoblastoma with mental retardation and dysmorphic facies (13q14.1); Prader-Willi syndrome (hypotonia, mental retardation and obesity, 15qll); Rubinstein Taybi syndrome (microcephaly, broad thumbs and big toes, dysmorphism and mental retardation; 16q13); and DiGeorge syndrome (congenital heart defect, hypoplasia of parathyroid and thymus, facial and palate anomalies; 22qll). Genomic imprinting - Prader-Willi syndrome (microdeletion on paternal side or inheritance of both copies from maternal side) and Angelman syndrome (microdeletion on maternal side or inheritance of both copies from paternal side).
  • • Nondisjunction - Common aneuploidies seen in live born babies include Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edward syndrome (trisomy 18), Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Turner syndrome (monosorny X).
  • • Nondisjunction
  • • aneuploidies
  • • live born babies
  • • Down syndrome
  • • Edward syndrome
  • • Patau syndrome
  • • Turner syndrome
  • • Chromosome deletion - William syndrome (7qll.23); retinoblastoma with mental retardation and dysmorphic facies (13q14.1); Prader-Willi syndrome (hypotonia, mental retardation and obesity, 15qll); Rubinstein Taybi syndrome (microcephaly, broad thumbs and big toes, dysmorphism and mental retardation; 16q13); and DiGeorge syndrome (congenital heart defect, hypoplasia of parathyroid and thymus, facial and palate anomalies; 22qll).
  • • Chromosome deletion
  • • William syndrome
  • • Genomic imprinting - Prader-Willi syndrome (microdeletion on paternal side or inheritance of both copies from maternal side) and Angelman syndrome (microdeletion on maternal side or inheritance of both copies from paternal side).
  • • Genomic imprinting
  • • Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition page 3023-24
  • • Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition page 3023-24

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: A premature baby, born at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1500 grams has stable vitals. What is the initial feeding method of choice? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.correct_answer: C. Orogastric tube / Alternative oral route
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube / Alternative oral route

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For a premature baby born at 33 weeks of gestation with stable vitals, the preferred initial feeding method is oral feeding by spoon, paladai, or cup. If the baby cannot take an adequate amount of feeding by these methods, orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding should be initiated. This approach ensures that the baby receives sufficient nutrition while accommodating their developmental feeding abilities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Intravenous fluids: Typically used for extremely premature infants or those unable to tolerate enteral feeding.
  • • Option A. Intravenous fluids:
  • • Option B. Intravenous fluids and oral feeding: This combination may be used in specific cases but is not the first choice for stable preterm infants at 33 weeks.
  • • Option
  • • B. Intravenous fluids and oral feeding:
  • • Option D. Total parenteral nutrition: Generally reserved for infants who cannot tolerate enteral feeding.
  • • Option D. Total parenteral nutrition:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable preterm infants born at 33 weeks, the initial feeding method of choice is orogastric tube or alternative oral routes such as spoon, paladai, or cup feeding.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 21%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

questions.text: A child has features of meningitis with following CSF examination: protein=93, glucose=20, Lymphocytes + Diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the CSF findings associated with different types of meningitis. Understand that the CSF profile, including elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis, can be indicative of tubercular meningitis. Be aware of the various etiologies and clinical presentations of meningitis in pediatric patients.

questions.text: A mother with a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis is being counselled. She is concerned about the risk of transmitting the infection to her newborn through breastfeeding. The Pediatrician advises her on when it would be safe to resume breastfeeding after starting antitubercular therapy. For how many weeks should breastfeeding be avoided after initiating antitubercular therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Breastfeeding is generally contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis until they have been on antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period to minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant . The mother should avoid breastfeeding for the initial 2 weeks of treatment , as this is typically the period necessary for the mother to become non-infectious.
  • • Breastfeeding
  • • contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis
  • • antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period
  • • minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant
  • • mother should avoid breastfeeding
  • • initial 2 weeks of treatment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommendations for breastfeeding in the context of maternal tuberculosis and antitubercular therapy . Mothers can often resume breastfeeding safely after the infectious period has passed , which is generally after the first 2 weeks of therapy.
  • ➤ recommendations for breastfeeding
  • ➤ maternal tuberculosis
  • ➤ antitubercular therapy
  • ➤ Mothers
  • ➤ resume breastfeeding safely
  • ➤ infectious period has passed
  • ➤ after the first 2 weeks of therapy.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old mother brings her 2-week-old neonate to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The neonate was delivered at term without any complications. The mother reports noticing multiple violet-black macules on the neonate's back and thigh since birth. The mother denies any family history of genetic disorders and states that the pregnancy was uneventful. On examination, the macules are well-demarcated, non-blanching, and do not appear to cause any discomfort to the neonate. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the condition observed in this neonate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a benign, self-limited transient condition

options.label: B
options.text: May result from a defect in migration of neural crest

options.label: C
options.text: May be associated with Hurler syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Malignant degeneration in 1% cases

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The diagnosis based on the clinical feature given is the Mongolian spots.
  • • Mongolian spots.
  • • They are a self-limited neural crest migration defect and occur in normal neonates , slowly fading with age . (option A) They are caused by the entrapment of melanocytes in the dermal layer during their migration from the neural crest to the epidermis in fetal development . (Option B) Extensive spots may occur in Hurler syndrome . (Option C) They do not require any therapy. There is no any chance of malignant degeneration.
  • • They are a self-limited neural crest migration defect and occur in normal neonates , slowly fading with age . (option A)
  • • They are a self-limited neural crest migration defect and occur in normal neonates , slowly fading with age . (option A)
  • • self-limited neural crest migration defect
  • • normal neonates
  • • slowly fading with age
  • • They are caused by the entrapment of melanocytes in the dermal layer during their migration from the neural crest to the epidermis in fetal development . (Option B)
  • • They are caused by the entrapment of melanocytes in the dermal layer during their migration from the neural crest to the epidermis in fetal development . (Option B)
  • • caused by the entrapment of melanocytes
  • • dermal layer
  • • migration from the neural crest
  • • epidermis in fetal development
  • • Extensive spots may occur in Hurler syndrome . (Option C)
  • • Extensive spots may occur in Hurler syndrome . (Option C)
  • • Extensive spots
  • • Hurler syndrome
  • • They do not require any therapy.
  • • They do not require any therapy.
  • • There is no any chance of malignant degeneration.
  • • There is no any chance of malignant degeneration.
  • • Other benign, transient neonatal changes seen are:
  • • benign, transient neonatal changes
  • • Transient neonatal pustular melanosis Erythema toxicum Breast enlargement Vaginal discharge Vernix caseosa Caput succedaneum Epstein pearls Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • • Transient neonatal pustular melanosis
  • • Transient neonatal pustular melanosis
  • • Erythema toxicum
  • • Erythema toxicum
  • • Breast enlargement
  • • Breast enlargement
  • • Vaginal discharge
  • • Vaginal discharge
  • • Vernix caseosa
  • • Vernix caseosa
  • • Caput succedaneum
  • • Caput succedaneum
  • • Epstein pearls
  • • Epstein pearls
  • • Subconjunctival hemorrhages
  • • Subconjunctival hemorrhages

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mongolian spots / congenital dermal melanocytosis - These spots are common , especially in individuals of Asian , African , and Latino descent , and are characterized by blue-gray to blue-black macules , typically located on the lumbosacral area . These spots occur due to ectopic melanocytes in dermis , disappear spontaneously by early childhood.
  • ➤ Mongolian spots
  • ➤ congenital dermal melanocytosis
  • ➤ common
  • ➤ individuals of Asian
  • ➤ African
  • ➤ Latino descent
  • ➤ blue-gray
  • ➤ blue-black macules
  • ➤ located on the lumbosacral area
  • ➤ spots
  • ➤ ectopic melanocytes in dermis
  • ➤ Note - Rarely Mongolian spots are associated with Hurler or Hunter syndromes, GM1 gangliosidosis, Niemann-Pick disease, mucolipidosis, and mannosidosis.
  • ➤ Note - Rarely Mongolian spots are associated with Hurler or Hunter syndromes, GM1 gangliosidosis, Niemann-Pick disease, mucolipidosis, and mannosidosis.
  • ➤ Ref : Nelson 21 st Edition Page No- 13325
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Nelson 21 st Edition Page No- 13325

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a concerned mother presents with her baby, Anu, who hails from a region currently experiencing severe drought conditions. Upon examination, Anu appears severely malnourished, prompting an urgent need for nutritional assessment. To determine the extent of acute malnutrition in Anu, which of the following parameters would be most appropriate for evaluation?

options.label: A
options.text: Height for age of the child.

options.label: B
options.text: Weight for height of the child.

options.label: C
options.text: Weight for age of the child.

questions.correct_answer: B. Weight for height of the child.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Weight for height of the child.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Height for Age : This parameter is used to assess stunting , which indicates chronic malnutrition . It reflects the long-term nutritional and health status of the child and is not the best indicator for acute malnutrition.
  • • Option A. Height for Age
  • • used to assess stunting
  • • indicates chronic malnutrition
  • • Option C. Weight for Age : This combines both acute and chronic aspects of malnutrition , making it less specific for acute malnutrition . It can indicate underweight status but doesn't distinguish between stunting (chronic malnutrition) and wasting (acute malnutrition).
  • • Option C. Weight for Age
  • • combines both acute and chronic aspects of malnutrition
  • • less specific for acute malnutrition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute malnutrition is also known as wasting & the parameter affected is weight for height
  • ➤ Acute malnutrition
  • ➤ wasting & the parameter
  • ➤ weight for height
  • ➤ Ref - Op Ghai 9 th Edition, Page No- 93.
  • ➤ Ref - Op Ghai 9 th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? ( INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

questions.text: A child has presented with a birth defect as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Craniorachischisis with anencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect involving both the brain and spinal cord, with the worst prognosis among neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta, in contrast, has the best prognosis among these conditions.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022) Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence. Cotrimoxazole is not given. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Enteroviruses are the most common cause of viral meningoencephalitis in children. These viruses are a leading cause of viral infections affecting the central nervous system, particularly in children. They typically cause a range of symptoms from mild febrile illness to severe meningoencephalitis. While other viruses like mumps, arboviruses, and HSV can also cause meningoencephalitis, enteroviruses are the most frequently identified causative agents in pediatric cases.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mumps: While it can cause meningoencephalitis, it is less common than enterovirus.
  • • Option A. Mumps:
  • • Option B. Arbovirus: These viruses are important causes of epidemic encephalitis but are not the most common in children.
  • • Option B. Arbovirus:
  • • Option C. HSV: Herpes simplex virus is a significant cause of sporadic encephalitis but not the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.
  • • Option C. HSV:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enteroviruses are the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.
